document.docAuthor: Brescovit, Antonio D., Ruiz, Alexander Sánchez & Garcia, Giraldo Alayón
document.masterDocTitle: The Filistatidae in the Caribbean region, with a description of the new genus Antilloides, revision of the genus Filistatoides F. O. P. - Cambridge and notes on Kukulcania Lehtinen (Arachnida, Araneae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Filistatidae in the Caribbean region, with a description of the new genus Antilloides, revision of the genus Filistatoides F. O. P. - Cambridge and notes on Kukulcania Lehtinen (Arachnida, Araneae)

heading.emphasis:
Filistatoides polita (
Franganillo, 1936
)
, sp. reval., n. comb.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Filistata polita
Franganillo, 1936
: 37
, figs 15‒16 ( Syntypes male and female from Cuba , Pastor Alayo and F. Balboa col., deposited in IES 53 and 54 respectively, examined).

Filistatoides insignis:
Alayón, 1972
: 7
‒8, figs 4‒5 (syn. with
F. polita
, misidentification).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2A‒H.
Filistatoides insignis O.P. Cambridge
, male palp (Iztapa, Santa Rosa, Guatemala). A. Bulb, prolateral. B. Same, ventral. C. Cymbium, detail, prolateral. D. Tibiae, distal area, ventral. E. Embolus, distal area, prolateral. F. Same, frontal. G. Arthrodial membrane (arrow) between cymbium and tibia, distal area. H. Tarsal organ.

FIGURE 3A‒E.
Filistatoides polita (Franganillo)
. A. Male (Dos Caminos de San Luis, Santiago de Cuba, Cuba), habitus dorsal. B. Female (same place), habitus dorsal. C. Male palp, prolateral. D. Same, retrolateral. E. Spermathecae, dorsal. Abbreviations: b = receptacle base; cd = neck; r = receptacula.

FIGURE 4A‒H.
Filistatoides polita (Franganillo)
, female (Dos Caminos de San Luis, Santiago de Cuba, Cuba), A‒D. Carapace, dorsal. A. Ocular area. B. Detail. C. Posterior region and pedicel. D. Thoracic groove and pedicel. E. Sternum and labium, ventral. F. Serrula, dorsal. G. Chelicerae, posterior. H. Chelicera detail, retromargin.

FIGURE 5A‒H.
Filistatoides polita (Franganillo)
female (Dos Caminos de San Luis, Santiago de Cuba, Cuba), A–E. Cribellum and spinnerets. A. Cribellum, ventral. B. Same, right spinning field, detail. C. Anterior lateral spinnerets, lateral. D. Same, ventral. E. Plumose setae, posterior median spinnerets, ventral. F. Pedipalp claw, lateral. G‒H. Legs, claws, lateral. G. Leg IV. H. Leg III, showing unpaired claw.

FIGURE 6A‒H.
Filistatoides polita (Franganillo)
, Dos Caminos de San Luis, Santiago de Cuba, Cuba. A. Female, dorsal surface of leg III showing chemosensory setae and sensilla. B. Same, grouped sensillae. C. Male palp. D. Same, arthrodial membrane between cymbium and tibia, distal area. E. Embolus, distal area. F. Same, retrolateral. G. Same, dorsal. 24. Same, ventral.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Note .
Filistata polita
was synonymized with
Filistatoides insignis
by
Alayón ( 1972 )
, who not examined the types . We examined the types of
Filistatoides insignis
and compared them with the types of
F. polita
Franganillo ( 1936 , fig. 16 )
that were recently located in the IES collection. The male palps, of
Filistata polita
types resemble those of
Filistatoides insignis
by the presence of the cylindrical palpal tibiae without a dorsal-retrolateral projection, which is diagnostic to the genus
Filistatoides
; but can be distinguished by its strongly curved embolus (
Figs 3 C‒D
,
6 C
,
8 E‒F
) with many projections on the tip (
Fig. 6 E‒H
). Moreover, additional material examined from several Cuban localities provided only specimens assignable to
Filistata polita
which seems to be endemic to this island. Therefore, we are revalidating this species and transferring it to
Filistatoides .

Other material examined. CUBA . Pinar del Río Province : Viñales, Cueva del Cable (
22 ° 40 ' 11.4 "N
83 ° 42 ' 23.1 "W
), 1 ♀, 1 imm.,
20 .IV. 2012
, A. Sánchez ( IBSP 166735 ). Camagüey Province : La Vigia (

), 1 ♀, 1 imm.,
02.VI. 2005
, A, Sánchez ( IBSP 166708 ); Sibanicú (in a house) (

), 1 Ƌ 2 ♀, 12 imm.,

,

, A. Sánchez & R. Teruel ( IBSP 166705 ); Ditto, 3 ♀ ( IBSP 166714 ); 2 Ƌ 2 ♀, 15 imm. (MNHNCu).

Diagnosis .
Filistatoides polita
can be distinguished from other species by the strongly curved embolus (
Figs 3 C‒D
,
6 C
,
8 E‒F
) with many projections on the tip (
Fig. 6 E‒H
). Females can be distinguished by the elongate base of the spermathecae with thicker necks than in other species (
Figs 3 E
,
8 G
).

Female (Same as male, IBSP 166704 ). Coloration as in male (
Fig. 3 B
). Total length 4.5 . Carapace length 1.7 , width 1.2 . PME separated by half their diameter. Palp measurements: femur 0.9 long, patella 0.4 long. Leg measurements: I femur 1.8 / patella 0.5 / tibia 2.1 / metatarsus 1.7 / tarsus 0.9 / total 7.0; II 1.4 / 0.5 / 1.2 / 1.1 / 0.8 / 5.0; III 1.1 / 0.4 / 0.9 / 0.9 / 0.7 / 4.0; IV 1.6 / 0.5 / 1.3 / 1.2 / 0.7 / 5.3 . Abdomen 2.5 long. Spermathecae with a large base leading to thicker than base neck (
Figs 3 E
,
8 G
).
Natural history . Specimens were collected in villages and rural areas from Cuba , mainly associated to walls in synanthropic environments.

Distribution. Known only from Cuba (
Fig. 22
C).
